title: C1: Org-Level Thinking
description: Sees and shapes cross-team systems, tradeoffs, and long-horizon outcomes.

title: C2: Strategic Prioritization
description: Defines and defends prioritization across competing investments.

title: C3: Systems Design & Architecture
description: Designs resilient systems and organizational structures that scale.

title: C4: Operational Leadership & Rhythm
description: Establishes operating cadences and ensures reliable delivery.

title: C5: Cross-Functional Influence
description: Aligns peers and leaders through influence, not authority.

title: C6: Coaching & Talent Development
description: Develops ICs and managers through 1:1s, career conversations, and growth-focused leadership.

title: C7: Decision Framing & Communication
description: Frames complex choices clearly with options, tradeoffs, and risks.

title: C8: Incidents, Risk & Reliability
description: Manages incidents, extracts systemic fixes, and drives operational risk reduction.

title: C9: Metrics, Measurement & Outcomes
description: Defines success metrics and uses data to validate decisions.

title: C10: Resource Allocation & Tradeoffs
description: Allocates budget, headcount, and attention to maximize long-term value.

title: C11: Hiring, Onboarding & Role Design
description: Designs hiring processes, ramps teams effectively, and builds talent brand.

title: C12: Culture & Norms Shaping
description: Uses signals, rituals, and policy to shape team culture and psychological safety.

title: C13: Security & Compliance Posture
description: Drives proactive security governance, vulnerability management, and compliance readiness.

title: C14: Performance Management & Calibration
description: Runs the performance cycle: reviews, calibration, ratings, PIPs, and exits with rigor and fairness.

title: C1-O1: Designs team topology aligned to value streams and cognitive load
description: Reorganizes from layer-based to stream-aligned teams, mapping ownership to customer value flows with clear boundaries.

title: C1-O2: Applies inverse Conway maneuver to align org structure with target architecture
description: Restructures teams to match desired microservices architecture, enabling independent deployment per team.

title: C1-O3: Executes re-orgs with structured communication and zero regrettable attrition
description: Runs re-org of 30 engineers across 4 teams: managers told first, ICs within 24hrs, phased transition over 3 weeks, full productivity restored by week 4.

title: C1-O4: Recognizes re-org signals and acts before problems become crises
description: Identifies growing coordination overhead and unclear ownership across two teams, proposes and executes split before productivity degrades.

title: C1-O5: Maintains single-threaded ownership registry with no ambiguity
description: Builds and maintains service→team→on-call→contact registry; resolves disputes by escalation, not by sharing ownership.

title: C1-O6: Sets coherent org-level goals aligned to business strategy with visible cross-team dependencies
description: Creates cascading OKRs from business strategy to org objectives to team goals; maps cross-team dependencies; explicitly connects engineering work to business outcomes and revenue impact.

title: C1-O7: Monitors org health dashboard and intervenes on early signals
description: Tracks attrition, engagement scores, skip-level themes, and PTO usage monthly; catches burnout trend in one team before anyone resigns.

title: C1-O8: Leads org through crisis while maintaining delivery on critical path
description: During 20% RIF, owns communication, protects remaining team's morale, maintains delivery on top priorities, sees zero additional voluntary attrition for 6 months.

title: C1-O9: Delegates execution to EMs while operating at Director altitude
description: Defines explicit ownership boundaries: Director owns strategy, cross-team, upward comms; EMs own team execution, 1:1s, sprint management. EMs escalate to Director only when criteria met.

title: C1-O10: Considers second-order effects and system-wide implications of decisions
description: Before approving a team's velocity metric target, identifies that it would incentivize gaming and instead proposes a balanced scorecard approach.

title: C2-O1: Runs structured planning process aligning eng investment to business priorities
description: Leads H2 planning: gathers asks from PM/business/tech-debt/reliability, calculates real capacity, stack-ranks, gets stakeholder buy-in on final plan.

title: C2-O2: Declines requests by making trade-offs visible, not by saying no
description: Responds to scope request with: 'Yes, if we deprioritize X — would you like to make that trade-off?' with data on impact of each option.

title: C2-O3: Makes progress under ambiguity by matching decision rigor to reversibility
description: Classifies a technology choice as reversible, ships in 2 days instead of 2 weeks; classifies a data model change as irreversible, invests 3 weeks in analysis.

title: C2-O4: Challenges assumptions using first principles when situation demands fresh thinking
description: Questions why team is building a custom auth system; first-principles analysis reveals the original requirement no longer exists, saving 3 months of work.

title: C3-O1: Authors and maintains multi-quarter technical vision with clear migration path
description: Co-authors tech strategy doc with Staff engineers: current state → target state → migration path → success metrics. Reviews quarterly against delivery reality.

title: C3-O2: Runs architecture reviews covering service boundaries, modularity, and design quality
description: Creates RFC template with required sections, sets review cadence, evaluates service boundary decisions against team topology and cognitive load, maintains searchable decision log. Reviews prevent both monolith coupling and over-decomposition.

title: C3-O3: Makes build-vs-buy decisions using repeatable framework with TCO analysis
description: Evaluates vendor solution using 3-year TCO including maintenance, lock-in risk, and team capability fit; saves 6 eng-months by buying instead of building.

title: C3-O4: Manages tech debt systematically with explicit capacity allocation
description: Maintains debt inventory classified by severity, allocates 15-20% sprint capacity, tracks impact of paydown on delivery metrics.

title: C3-O5: Defines SLOs with error budgets that drive reliability trade-offs
description: Partners with SRE to set SLOs per service, defines error budgets, uses budget consumption as signal to slow feature work and invest in reliability.

title: C3-O6: Plans and executes migrations incrementally without business disruption
description: Uses strangler fig pattern to migrate system serving 10K QPS: parallel running with comparison testing, phased rollout with feature flags, zero customer-facing incidents.

title: C3-O7: Maintains observability standards and dependency maps enabling fast incident diagnosis
description: Defines structured logging format, required metrics per service, end-to-end trace propagation, and dependency maps with fallback strategies; reduces mean time to diagnose from 4 hours to 20 minutes.

title: C4-O1: Establishes operating cadences with clear purposes and measurable outputs
description: Creates quarterly planning, weekly ops review, and async status cadence — each with defined roles, inputs, and outputs. Eliminates 3 meetings with unclear purpose.

title: C4-O2: Tracks delivery commitments with measurable KPIs and >85% hit rate
description: Creates commitment tracking with planned-vs-delivered ratio, velocity trend, and carryover rate; team consistently delivers 85%+ of committed work.

title: C4-O3: Invests in developer experience and tooling with measurable productivity gains
description: Reduces CI pipeline from 45min to 8min, reclaiming 200 developer-hours/week; tracks build times, test duration, and local dev setup time.

title: C4-O4: Eliminates toil through automation with tracked capacity reclamation
description: Runs toil audit, identifies top 3 manual processes, automates them, reclaims equivalent of 1 FTE in capacity per quarter.

title: C4-O5: Implements risk-appropriate release process with automated rollback
description: Deploys with canary (1%→10%→50%→100%), automated rollback triggers on error rate spike, feature flags decoupling deploy from release.

title: C4-O6: Maintains code review culture with <24hr SLA and knowledge distribution
description: Sets review SLA target, implements reviewer rotation for knowledge spread, tracks review bottleneck trends.

title: C4-O7: Protects team focus with interrupt budget and scope change process
description: Designates rotating interrupt handler per sprint, defines escalation criteria for true urgency, requires explicit trade-off for any mid-sprint scope addition.

title: C4-O8: Runs retrospectives with >80% action item completion rate
description: Bi-weekly retros with strict format, action items with owners, tracked completion rate, specific process improvements implemented each quarter.

title: C5-O1: Maintains healthy Eng/PM/Design triad with joint roadmap ownership
description: Runs weekly triad syncs with shared context: PM shares business data, Design shares user research, Eng shares technical constraints. Disagreements resolved through data, not hierarchy.

title: C5-O2: Navigates PM disagreements by framing trade-offs in business terms
description: Responds to PM's deadline pressure by quantifying tech debt cost: 'This approach costs 200 eng-hours in maintenance over 3 quarters' and proposes three options with trade-offs.

title: C5-O3: Proactively shapes product strategy through technical insight
description: Identifies a new API capability that enables a product surface PM hadn't considered; presents with user impact framing, leading to a roadmap pivot.

title: C5-O4: Resolves cross-team dependencies through partnership, not escalation
description: Builds relationship with partner EM before needing anything; frames dependency request as mutual benefit; unblocks project without VP involvement.

title: C5-O5: Builds effective partnerships with platform, infra, and support functions
description: Joins platform team's planning process, provides clear requirements with business justification, contributes bug fixes back; team's needs reflected in platform roadmap.

title: C5-O6: Manages up intentionally to build trust, autonomy, and sponsorship
description: Understands manager's priorities; brings solutions not just problems; pre-wires before surprises; manager advocates for team in rooms they're not in.

title: C5-O7: Builds political capital through consistent delivery and helping others succeed
description: Accumulates trust by: delivering consistently, sharing credit, unblocking peer teams, following through on every commitment. Trusted advisor for domain decisions.

title: C5-O8: Pre-wires alignment across orgs before formal decision meetings
description: Has 1:1 conversations with each stakeholder before group meeting; creates shared context document; proposes strawman for reaction. Drives convergence without VP forcing it.

title: C5-O9: Builds sponsor relationships with senior leaders for visibility and advocacy
description: Delivers visible results, presents at VP reviews, volunteers for cross-org initiatives; VP sponsors them for scope expansion.

title: C5-O10: Navigates scope ambiguity by demonstrating capability, not political maneuvering
description: When scope between two orgs is ambiguous, demonstrates competence by delivering in the space; frames expansion in terms of customer benefit; builds coalition of supporters.

title: C6-O1: Runs structured 1:1s that build trust and drive career development
description: Weekly 1:1s with shared doc; 60% their agenda / 20% yours / 20% career; follows through on every commitment. Skip-level feedback confirms quality.

title: C6-O2: Addresses underperformance early with clear expectations and genuine support
description: Verifies expectations were clear, documents specific gaps with examples, sets improvement plan with milestones, holds weekly check-ins; person either improves or exits with dignity.

title: C6-O3: Identifies flight risk through behavioral signals and intervenes proactively
description: Notices reduced engagement and vague answers about future plans from key engineer; conducts stay interview, surfaces growth concern, creates stretch assignment. Engineer stays.

title: C6-O4: Manages high performers with increasing scope, visibility, and sponsorship
description: Quarterly career conversations with top talent; provides stretch assignments, visibility opportunities, and comp advocacy. Grows senior engineer to staff through deliberate sponsorship.

title: C6-O5: Designs stretch assignments that build promotion evidence through real work
description: Identifies business need as stretch opportunity for engineer; provides clear expectations, check-in cadence, and safety net. Engineer demonstrates next-level capability and gets promoted.

title: C6-O6: Coaches EMs through management situations using scenario-based development
description: Weekly 1:1s focused on management craft, not just status. Walks EM through 'your engineer says they're burned out' scenario; EM develops independent judgment over 6 months.

title: C6-O7: Builds manager bench through intentional EM pipeline development
description: Identifies high-potential ICs, creates TL rotation opportunities, runs EM-in-training program with shadowing. Manager transitions happen with zero team disruption.

title: C7-O1: Frames decisions with options, trade-offs, and clear recommendation
description: Sends decision memo with 3 options, quantified trade-offs, recommended path, and anticipated objections. Decision is made in first review meeting.

title: C7-O2: Adapts communication altitude to audience — exec summary to detailed appendix
description: Creates one-slide exec memo for VP and detailed appendix for engineering; same content, different altitude. Both audiences get what they need.

title: C7-O3: Communicates status proactively — wins, risks, and needs — earning autonomy
description: Weekly written update to manager: top 3 wins, top 3 risks, what I need from you. Manager says: 'always knows what's happening, no surprises.'

title: C7-O4: Delivers bad news early with ownership and a mitigation plan
description: Flags project slip 3 weeks before deadline with root cause, impact assessment, and 2 mitigation options. Leadership thanks them for transparency.

title: C7-O5: Delivers crisp executive presentations driving decisions within allotted time
description: Pyramid-structured 5-slide business review: conclusion first, supporting metrics, anticipated questions prepared. Earns invitation to future strategy discussions.

title: C7-O6: Implements DACI/RFC frameworks that reduce decision revisitation
description: Establishes DACI roles for every significant decision; RFC template with 5-day comment period and escalation path. Decision revisitation drops measurably.

title: C7-O7: Communicates roadmap trade-offs with explicit 'what we're NOT doing' section
description: Every planning doc includes de-prioritized items with rationale; new requests require explicit deprioritization trade-off visible to all stakeholders.

title: C8-O1: Runs incident command with clear roles, reducing Sev1 duration measurably
description: Implements ICS model: IC, Comms Lead, Ops Lead. Quarterly game days to practice. Sev1 duration reduced 40% after adoption.

title: C8-O2: Drives blameless post-mortems with >90% action item completion
description: Structured template with timeline, 5-whys, systemic action items with owners and deadlines. Tracks completion rate; repeat incident rate drops measurably.

title: C8-O3: Maintains healthy on-call with <2 off-hours pages/night and low false-positive rate
description: Tracks pages per rotation, off-hours pages, and false positive rate. Runs noise reduction sprints when thresholds exceeded. Engineers willing to be on-call.

title: C8-O4: Conducts proactive failure mode analysis and launch readiness reviews
description: Pre-mortem before major launch identifies 5 failure modes; mitigation in place for each. Launch checklist gates deployment. Zero Sev1s on launches for 4 consecutive quarters.

title: C9-O1: Tracks DORA metrics with trend analysis and targeted bottleneck removal
description: Instruments CI/CD pipeline for all 4 DORA metrics; identifies review bottleneck as longest stage; reduces lead time from 5 days to 8 hours by implementing review SLA.

title: C9-O2: Measures developer satisfaction and acts on friction signals before they become attrition
description: Quarterly 5-question developer experience survey; identifies tooling frustration as top theme; invests in fix; next quarter satisfaction improves and attrition risk decreases.

title: C9-O3: Uses activity metrics as diagnostic signals, never as performance measures
description: Dashboards show team-level patterns (PR throughput, review turnaround) to spot blocked teams; explicitly bans individual-level activity metrics from perf evaluation.

title: C9-O4: Defines outcome-oriented OKRs with measurable key results scored quarterly
description: Max 3 objectives per team per quarter; all key results measurable; includes 1 stretch; bi-weekly check-in; quarterly scoring drives real priority decisions.

title: C9-O5: Translates engineering outcomes into business metrics leadership values
description: Maps latency reduction to conversion rate lift, framing infrastructure investment as '$2M ARR impact' rather than 'p99 improvement.'

title: C9-O6: Classifies attrition and identifies systemic retention patterns
description: Categorizes each departure as regrettable vs non-regrettable; identifies that 3 of 4 regrettable departures cited lack of growth; implements fix.

title: C10-O1: Builds headcount cases with capacity model, impact projection, and ROI
description: Secures 4 headcount by demonstrating: current capacity gap, business impact if unfilled, 3x ROI projection within 12 months, prioritized role ranking.

title: C10-O2: Reprioritizes aggressively during cuts, communicating what stops — not just what continues
description: During 15% budget cut: stack-ranks all work, pauses bottom 20%, communicates cuts to stakeholders explicitly, maintains delivery on top-3 priorities.

title: C10-O3: Manages cloud/infra costs with attribution, targets, and optimization results
description: Implements cost attribution per service, monthly cost review, optimization targets; reduces cloud costs 25% ($500K annual savings) through right-sizing and reserved instances.

title: C10-O4: Optimizes team composition with principled FTE/contractor/vendor mix
description: Evaluates work types: core differentiating work→FTE, commodity/surge work→contractor, specialized work→vendor. Saves 20% while maintaining velocity.

title: C10-O5: Defends critical investments during cuts by articulating business consequences
description: Protects platform team during 20% budget cut by demonstrating: cutting team means 5 product teams lose deploy capability, impacting $10M revenue. Proposes alternative savings instead.

title: C11-O1: Runs calibrated hiring loops with trained interviewers and consistent bar
description: Defines competency matrix per role/level, trains interviewers through shadow cycle, enforces independent write-ups before group debrief, maintains bar raiser veto.

title: C11-O2: Maintains hiring bar under pressure — no warm body hires
description: Despite 4 open reqs for 6 months, passes on borderline candidates; eventual hires all rated 'strong hire' with zero regrettable offers.

title: C11-O3: Designs 30/60/90 onboarding with measurable ramp milestones
description: Week 1: first commit. Month 1: buddy-guided starter project. Month 2: independent feature delivery. Month 3: full autonomy. Ramp time reduced from 90 to 45 days.

title: C11-O4: Collects and acts on onboarding feedback, improving program each cohort
description: 30/60/90 surveys with 5 questions; identifies that documentation gaps slow ramp; fixes docs; next cohort ramps 2 weeks faster.

title: C11-O5: Builds continuous sourcing pipeline through referrals and technical brand
description: Creates team referral culture, publishes engineering blog posts showcasing team's work, supports conference talks; fills roles through referrals in avg 30 days.

title: C11-O6: Articulates clear team value proposition driving higher offer acceptance
description: Defines and maintains: what problems we solve, what scale we operate at, what you'll learn, career path, culture. Offer acceptance rate improves from 60% to 80%.

title: C12-O1: Models psychological safety through personal vulnerability and constructive response to bad news
description: Shares own mistakes publicly; responds to production incident disclosure with 'tell me more' not 'how did this happen'; team health survey shows safety scores above org average.

title: C12-O2: Establishes team charter and engineering principles that guide daily decisions
description: Collaboratively drafts team charter covering values, communication norms, and decision process. Creates 3-5 engineering principles referenced in design reviews.

title: C12-O3: Institutionalizes knowledge sharing that reduces bus factor and accelerates onboarding
description: Implements bi-weekly tech talks, documentation standards (every system has README + runbook + design doc), design doc culture. Documentation coverage goes from 40% to 90%.

title: C12-O4: Implements recognition rituals that reinforce desired behaviors
description: Weekly shout-outs in team sync tied to engineering principles; peer recognition channel. Recognition is specific ('Sarah's design doc saved 2 weeks of rework') not generic ('good job').

title: C12-O5: Drives inclusive practices ensuring equitable opportunity distribution
description: Uses round-robin facilitation, async participation options, and equitable stretch assignment distribution. Promotion rates equitable across demographics.

title: C13-O1: Embeds security checkpoints in development workflow as automatic gates
description: Threat modeling during design phase using STRIDE; automated SAST/DAST in CI; security champion rotation; pre-launch security checklist. Zero last-minute security blockers.

title: C13-O2: Manages vulnerabilities within severity-based SLAs with tracked patch velocity
description: Automated dependency scanning in CI; Critical: 48hr, High: 1 week, Medium: 1 month. Zero critical CVEs beyond SLA for 6 consecutive quarters.

title: C13-O3: Enforces least-privilege access with quarterly reviews and auto-expiring elevation
description: Quarterly access reviews, role-based access aligned to on-call rotation, temporary elevation for debugging that auto-expires, full audit trail.

title: C13-O4: Maintains continuous compliance posture with automated evidence collection
description: Automated compliance checks in CI/CD; evidence collection pipelines; quarterly self-audit against controls; compliance dashboard. Clean audit for 4 consecutive cycles with zero findings.

title: C14-O1: Writes evidence-based performance reviews with level-anchored assessment
description: Collects feedback continuously using impact log; uses level rubric language explicitly; reviews are specific ('drove X resulting in Y, demonstrating next-level Z') not vague ('did great work').

title: C14-O2: Prepares calibration cases with evidence portfolio and anticipated pushback
description: Per person: 1-page impact portfolio with top 3 achievements, peer feedback synthesis, cross-team comparison context, counter-arguments prepared. Expected ratings achieved consistently.

title: C14-O3: Navigates ratings distribution with honest differentiation and zero escalations
description: Understands company's specific distribution curve; differentiates honestly without inflating; invests preparation proportional to contested ratings.

title: C14-O4: Delivers performance feedback within 48hrs using SBI framework
description: Uses Situation→Behavior→Impact framework for all feedback. Never saves feedback for perf review. Direct reports consistently confirm in skip-levels: 'I know where I stand.'

title: C14-O5: Builds promotion evidence over multiple cycles with deliberate gap-filling
description: Starts building promo case 2-3 cycles before target; maps work to next-level rubric; identifies gaps; creates stretch opportunities to fill them; gets pre-reads from calibration peers.

title: C14-O6: Runs fair PIPs with genuine support and clean process — zero procedural issues
description: Specific gaps with examples, measurable criteria, 30-60 day timeline, weekly check-ins with documented progress, genuine coaching and resources. HR sees them as reliable partner.

title: C1-O11: Identifies platform opportunities and builds teams that reduce org-wide cognitive load
description: Justified and built internal platform team providing self-service deployment, observability, and auth. 8 stream-aligned teams adopted, saving estimated 12 eng-months/quarter of duplicated effort.

title: C1-O12: Navigates externally-imposed changes (re-orgs, new leadership) while maintaining team stability
description: VP announces re-org splitting team; guides team through transition with honest communication about what's known/unknown, preserves key relationships, maintains velocity, zero attrition. Builds trust with new leadership within 30 days.

title: C1-O13: Conducts structured assessment of inherited team within first 30 days
description: In first 30 days as new EM: mapped people (strengths, aspirations, concerns), processes (what works, what's broken), and systems (tech debt, reliability gaps). Identified 4 key issues, built trust through listening before initiating changes in month 2.

title: C3-O8: Conducts proactive capacity planning and identifies platform consolidation opportunities
description: Anticipated 3x load for product launch: pre-scaled infrastructure with zero downtime. Identified that 4 teams built separate caching layers; proposed consolidated platform approach saving $800K/year.

title: C4-O9: Establishes runbook culture ensuring every alert has documented remediation steps
description: Every page in PagerDuty links to a runbook. New on-call engineers handle incidents independently within first rotation. Runbook coverage: 95% of alerts, reviewed quarterly.

title: C4-O10: Implements tiered change management proportional to risk level, preventing change-induced incidents
description: Tiered process: automated checks for config changes, peer review + staged rollout for schema migrations, full approval + maintenance window for cross-service changes. All production changes tracked and auditable. Change-related incidents reduced 65%.

title: C4-O11: Adapts team practices for remote/hybrid work ensuring equal engagement regardless of location
description: Manages distributed team across 3 timezones: async-first communication, recorded decisions in shared docs, defined overlap hours for real-time collaboration. No proximity bias in stretch assignments or promotions.

title: C5-O11: Navigates leadership transitions by rebuilding trust proactively within 30 days
description: New VP arrives with different priorities. Within 2 weeks: scheduled intro, presented team portfolio with business impact framing, identified 2 alignment opportunities. VP trust established before first planning cycle.

title: C5-O12: Partners with Legal/Privacy/Policy teams to build reusable patterns that eliminate launch-blocking reviews
description: Built pre-approved design patterns for PII handling, consent flows, and data residency. Reduced launch-blocking legal reviews from 3 weeks to 2 days for 80% of launches.

title: C5-O13: Earns early credibility as new leader through quick wins and listening before changing
description: First 90 days: spent weeks 1-3 in listening mode (skip-levels, stakeholder intros, codebase review). Identified quick win (flaky test fix) in week 4. Delivered by week 6. Earned mandate for larger changes.

title: C6-O8: Conducts systematic stay interviews surfacing retention drivers before they become exit interviews
description: Instituted quarterly stay interviews with all direct reports. Surfaced comp band concern across 3 engineers. Addressed with market adjustment before any resignations.

title: C6-O9: Manages Staff+ engineers with calibrated autonomy, influence opportunities, and organizational sponsorship
description: Partnered with Staff engineer: co-owned technical vision, provided organizational air cover, created VP-visibility opportunities. Staff engineer led cross-org migration, cited partnership in promo packet.

title: C6-O10: Drives career development through structured career conversations distinct from performance feedback
description: Separated career conversations from performance check-ins. Monthly career 1:1 focused on 18-month aspirations, skill gaps, and growth experiments. 100% of reports have written development plans.

title: AP-01: The Absent Architect — EM defers all technical direction to TL/Staff and has no opinion on system evolution
description: No tech strategy doc exists; architecture decisions are ad hoc; design reviews are inconsistent or skipped; tech debt is invisible until it causes incidents

title: AP-02: The Over-Involved Architect — EM makes every technical decision, bypassing TL/seniors
description: EM reviews all PRs; design docs require EM approval; senior engineers are disempowered; EM is the bottleneck for every decision

title: AP-03: Metrics Theater — tracking DORA/SPACE dashboards without acting on them, or gaming metrics
description: Beautiful dashboards nobody looks at; metrics improve but team doesn't feel faster; metrics targets become team KPIs used in performance reviews; 'deploy frequency' gamed by splitting deploys

title: AP-04: Velocity Obsession — optimizing for shipping speed while quality, reliability, and sustainability degrade
description: Rising change failure rate alongside rising deployment frequency; increasing on-call pages; growing tech debt backlog; team working overtime 'to ship'; cutting testing 'to move faster'

title: AP-05: Security As Someone Else's Problem — EM treats security as the security team's job, not the engineering team's responsibility
description: Security reviews are afterthoughts or skipped; vulnerabilities linger beyond SLA; team doesn't know basic security practices; 'we'll fix it after launch'

title: AP-06: Hero Culture — incidents resolved by the same 2-3 people every time; tribal knowledge instead of process
description: Same people always on incident calls; no runbooks; new team members useless during incidents; MTTR depends on who's on-call; hero engineers burned out

title: AP-07: Blame Post-Mortems — post-incident analysis becomes finger-pointing, driving incidents underground
description: People avoid documenting what went wrong; root causes listed as 'human error'; defensive language in post-mortems; fewer incidents reported (not fewer incidents occurring); near-misses never discussed

title: AP-08: Re-org Addiction — constantly restructuring teams instead of solving underlying problems
description: More than one re-org per year; teams never stabilize; people joke about 'the next re-org'; leadership sees re-orgs as solutions to execution problems

title: AP-09: Fuzzy Ownership — multiple teams think they own the same thing, or nobody owns it
description: Incidents where 3 teams are paged and nobody acts; features that 'slip through the cracks'; cross-team meetings to figure out 'who should build this'; duplicate implementations discovered

title: AP-10: Conflict Avoidance — EM avoids difficult conversations, lets problems fester, gives vague feedback
description: Underperformers coasting for quarters; team frustration about 'dead weight'; EM gives everyone positive feedback; real issues discussed in back-channels; skip-level 1:1s reveal problems EM hasn't addressed

title: AP-11: The Bubble — EM only hears good news because team doesn't feel safe sharing problems
description: EM thinks team is happy; engagement survey results are surprising; problems discovered through incidents or attrition, not through communication; 1:1s are pleasant but shallow

title: AP-12: The 24/7 Manager — EM is always available, always responsive, and burning out while modeling unsustainable behavior
description: EM responds to Slack at midnight; team feels guilty taking PTO because EM never does; EM can't delegate because 'it's faster to do it myself'; EM's manager doesn't know EM is underwater

title: AP-13: Lowering the Bar Under Pressure — hiring warm bodies because reqs are open and leadership is asking
description: Declining interview scores accepted with 'we need someone'; onboarding problems increase; regrettable hires within 12 months; team quality diluted

title: AP-14: The Clone Factory — hiring people who look, think, and work exactly like the current team
description: Homogeneous team; same backgrounds and perspectives; groupthink in design reviews; interview process unconsciously filters for 'culture fit' meaning 'like us'

title: AP-15: The Permanent PIP — using performance management as punishment instead of genuine development tool
description: PIPs designed to fail; documentation started only when exit decision already made; no real coaching or support during PIP; team perceives PIPs as 'you're being fired slowly'

title: AP-16: Promotion as Retention — promoting people who aren't ready to prevent them from leaving
description: Engineers promoted without next-level evidence; newly promoted engineers struggling at new level; promo rate high but calibration pushback increasing; 'title inflation'

title: AP-17: The Lake Wobegon Effect — rating everyone above average, avoiding differentiation
description: All reports rated 'Exceeds Expectations'; calibration committee overrides your ratings; no one on your team has development areas in their review; skip-level feedback contradicts your assessments

title: AP-18: Culture by Accident — no intentional culture, just whatever norms emerge from the loudest personalities
description: Team norms driven by most senior/vocal person; new hires absorb unhealthy patterns; no written team charter; 'that's just how we do things' is the only explanation

title: AP-19: The Super-EM — Director who manages ICs through their EMs, undermining EM authority
description: ICs come to Director instead of their EM; Director gives direction that contradicts EM's plan; EMs feel like figureheads; Director in too many operational details

title: AP-20: Absent Director — delegates everything and disappears, providing no coaching, context, or support
description: EMs making conflicting decisions; no cross-team alignment; EMs don't know organizational context; Director can't articulate what their teams are doing; skip-level feedback: 'I never see my Director'

title: AP-21: The Feature Factory — team builds whatever PM asks without questioning whether it's the right investment
description: Roadmap is just PM's feature list; no engineering-initiated work; tech debt never prioritized; team can't articulate why they're building what they're building; no OKRs, just a Jira backlog

title: AP-22: The Adversarial Triad — Eng/PM/Design in constant conflict, treating each other as obstacles instead of partners
description: Blame between functions when things go wrong; PM and Eng have separate roadmaps; Design excluded from technical decisions; 'us vs them' language in team meetings

title: AP-23: The Surprise Factory — leadership learns about problems from other people, not from you
description: VP asks about a project delay you haven't reported; partner team escalates an issue you thought was contained; your manager is blindsided in a meeting; 'why am I hearing about this from [someone else]?'

title: AP-24: Empire Building — expanding scope for status rather than customer or business impact
description: Politicking for headcount without clear need; absorbing teams without clear benefit; optimizing for org size rather than org impact; 'more reports = more important'

title: AP-25: The Blank Check Mentality — asking for resources without cost consciousness or ROI justification
description: Every problem's solution is 'we need more headcount'; no cost tracking for cloud/infra; proposals lack ROI analysis; never voluntarily reducing spend; surprised by budget discussions

title: AP-26: Analysis Paralysis — every decision requires exhaustive analysis, committees, and consensus before action
description: Simple decisions take weeks; team waits for EM approval on everything; meetings to plan meetings; 'let's get more data' as default response; reversible decisions treated as irreversible

title: AP-27: The Yes Machine — agreeing to everything, never pushing back, never making trade-offs explicit
description: Team overcommitted; every stakeholder thinks their request is accepted; deadlines consistently missed; team working overtime; EM apologizing constantly

title: P-C6-1: Your Top Performer Gives 2 Weeks Notice
description: Your best senior engineer has an offer from a competitor. They seem decided but are giving you a courtesy conversation.

title: P-C8-1: Major Production Incident During Your Vacation
description: You're on vacation. A Sev1 incident fires and your team is handling it. Your manager pings you asking for status.

title: P-C5-1: PM Wants to Ship a Feature You Know Will Create Tech Debt
description: PM has committed to a deadline with stakeholders. Meeting the deadline requires cutting corners that will cost the team months of debt later.

title: P-C12-1: Two of Your Engineers Are in Conflict
description: Two senior engineers disagree on a technical approach. It's gotten personal — code reviews are hostile, standup is tense, team morale is affected.

title: P-C1-1: You Inherit a Low-Performing Team
description: You join as EM. In your first month you discover: 2 engineers should probably be on a PIP, the team's metrics are worst in the org, morale is low, and the previous EM left because of burnout.

title: P-C1-2: Layoffs Are Coming and You Know Before Your Team
description: Your Director told you confidentially: 20% RIF next week. You know who's affected on your team. You can't tell anyone yet.

title: P-C5-2: Your New VP Wants to Change Everything
description: New VP joins. They want to re-org, change tech stack, adopt new processes, and reset all roadmaps. Your team is anxious.

title: P-C6-2: You Discover a Senior Engineer Is Quietly Job Searching
description: Through the grapevine (or obvious calendar gaps), you realize one of your senior engineers is interviewing elsewhere. They haven't told you.

title: P-C3-1: Your Team Needs to Deliver a Critical Migration Under Tight Deadline
description: Leadership committed to migrating off a legacy system in Q3. Your team owns it. The deadline is real (vendor contract expiration). Scope is larger than estimated.
capabilityName: Systems Design & Architecture, Operational Leadership & Rhythm

title: P-C14-1: Calibration Committee Wants to Downgrade Your Engineer's Rating
description: You submitted 'Exceeds Expectations' for a strong senior engineer. In calibration, peer managers are pushing for 'Meets' based on cross-team comparison. You disagree.

title: P-C1-3: A Cross-Team Initiative Is Stalled Because No One Owns It
description: An important cross-org project has been discussed for months but nobody is driving it. Multiple teams would benefit but each expects the other to lead.

title: P-C14-2: Your Manager Asks You to Rate Everyone 'Meets Expectations'
description: Your Director says the org needs to compress ratings this cycle. They want fewer 'Exceeds' ratings. You have 3 engineers who genuinely exceeded.

title: P-C11-1: You Need to Build a New Team From Scratch
description: You've been given headcount to build a new team for a greenfield project. You have 6 months to hire 6 engineers and deliver first milestone.

title: P-C6-3: One of Your EMs Is Struggling (Director Scenario)
description: One of your EMs is underperforming: their team's metrics are declining, skip-level feedback is concerning, and the EM seems overwhelmed.

title: P-C8-2: Production Outage Caused by Your Team's Deploy
description: Your team deployed a change that caused a major production incident. Customers are affected. Leadership is asking what happened.

title: P-C5-3: You're Asked to Take on Scope That Doesn't Fit Your Team
description: Your VP wants your team to own a new area that doesn't align with your team's expertise or mission. It's a political hot potato nobody else wants.

title: P-C5-4: A Key Platform Dependency Is Unreliable and the Platform Team Won't Prioritize Fixes
description: Your team's reliability is suffering because of an upstream platform dependency. The platform team acknowledges the issue but has higher priorities.

title: P-C12-2: Your Team Has Zero Diversity and You're Told to Fix It
description: HR/leadership points out your team is homogeneous. You're asked to 'improve diversity' in your next hires.
capabilityName: Culture & Norms Shaping, Hiring, Onboarding & Role Design

title: P-C7-1: You Strongly Disagree with a Decision Made Above You
description: Your Director/VP made a strategic decision you think is wrong. It directly affects your team's direction.

title: P-C5-5: You're Preparing for Your Own Promotion to Director
description: You've been a strong EM for 2+ years and want to make the jump to Director. What do you actually need to demonstrate?

title: P-C9-1: DORA Metrics Show Decline But Team Feels Fine
description: Your DORA metrics have been trending down for 2 quarters — deploy frequency dropped 40%, lead time increased 3x. But team morale is fine and nobody is complaining. Your VP saw the dashboard and is asking questions.

title: P-C10-1: Budget Cut: Lose 20% Headcount, Keep Critical Deliverables
description: Company announces 20% headcount reduction. You have 25 engineers across 4 teams. You need to identify 5 positions to cut while maintaining delivery on your top-3 commitments. You have 2 weeks before the announcement.

title: P-C13-1: Security Audit Finding: Critical Vulnerability in Production
description: Internal security audit found a critical vulnerability (e.g., unencrypted PII in logs, open S3 bucket, SQL injection vector) in your team's production service. Security team has given you a 72-hour remediation window. Your team is mid-sprint on a high-priority feature launch.

title: C1-O14: Leads engineering teams through M&A integration with codebase consolidation and talent retention
description: Led integration of 25-person acquired team: mapped overlapping services within 2 weeks, established unified coding standards by month 2, consolidated 3 duplicated services by month 4. Retained 92% of acquired engineers through intentional culture bridging and clear role mapping.

title: C1-O15: Manages divestiture and team wind-down with dignity, knowledge transfer, and minimal organizational disruption
description: Led wind-down of 15-person product team after strategic pivot: created comprehensive knowledge transfer plan within 1 week, placed 12 of 15 engineers into internal roles within 30 days, archived documentation for all critical systems, zero production incidents during transition.

title: C3-O9: Designs systems with cost consciousness and drives FinOps practices across the team
description: Implemented cost-aware architecture reviews: every design doc includes estimated cloud cost. Established FinOps practice with weekly cost dashboards per service. Identified $400K/year in overprovisioned compute, right-sized without performance impact. Engineering team owns cost as a first-class metric.

title: C3-O10: Incorporates sustainability and energy efficiency into architecture decisions and infrastructure planning
description: Implemented carbon-aware workload scheduling, shifting batch processing to low-carbon-intensity hours. Adopted ARM-based instances for stateless services, reducing energy consumption 30%. Reported sustainability metrics in quarterly business reviews.

title: C5-O14: Navigates multiple reporting lines and stakeholder alignment in matrix management structures
description: Reports to VP Engineering with dotted line to VP Product and CTO. Maintains weekly syncs with all three, aligns conflicting priorities through transparent trade-off communication. When priorities conflict, escalates with recommendation rather than forcing stakeholders to discover misalignment.

title: C5-O15: Prepares board-level materials that frame engineering investment as strategic business narrative
description: Authored engineering section of quarterly board deck: 3 slides covering platform reliability as competitive moat, R&D velocity benchmarked against industry, and talent pipeline as strategic risk. Board approved $2M infrastructure investment based on narrative.

title: C6-O11: Coaches struggling EMs through skill gaps with structured support and clear intervention criteria
description: Identified EM struggling with conflict resolution: team had 3 unresolved interpersonal issues. Created 90-day coaching plan with weekly role-play sessions, assigned mentor from senior EM pool, monitored via skip-level sentiment. EM resolved all issues by month 3 and cited coaching as career-defining.

title: C6-O12: Builds succession plans ensuring leadership continuity for all critical roles
description: Maintained succession matrix for all EM and TL roles: identified primary and secondary successors, documented readiness gaps, created development assignments to close gaps. When EM departed unexpectedly, successor stepped in with zero team disruption.

title: C8-O5: Manages regulatory compliance risk with proactive frameworks and audit-ready engineering practices
description: Built GDPR compliance framework for engineering: automated PII detection in data pipelines, consent management API used by 6 teams, data retention policies enforced programmatically. Passed SOC2 audit with zero engineering findings for 3 consecutive years.

title: C8-O6: Evaluates and manages vendor risk with structured assessment, dependency tracking, and contingency planning
description: Maintained vendor risk registry for 12 critical dependencies. Identified single-vendor lock-in for payment processing; negotiated multi-provider contract and built abstraction layer. When primary vendor had 8-hour outage, failover activated automatically with zero customer impact.

title: C9-O7: Governs feature flag lifecycle with creation standards, ownership tracking, and mandatory cleanup
description: Established feature flag governance: every flag has owner, expiry date, and cleanup ticket created at birth. Automated stale flag detection alerts at 30 days. Reduced active flags from 340 to 45. Eliminated 2 production incidents caused by forgotten flag interactions.

title: C9-O8: Enforces statistical rigor in A/B testing with proper design, power analysis, and result interpretation
description: Established A/B testing standards: mandatory power analysis before launch, minimum sample size gates, sequential testing for early stopping. Caught 3 experiments that would have shipped with underpowered results. Team stopped making decisions on p=0.08 results.

title: C11-O7: Optimizes diversity hiring pipeline with structured sourcing, bias reduction, and inclusive practices
description: Audited hiring funnel: identified 40% drop-off of underrepresented candidates at phone screen. Revised job descriptions removing exclusionary language, added structured scoring rubrics, partnered with 3 diversity-focused sourcing organizations. Underrepresented candidate pass-through rate improved 25% within 2 quarters.

title: C11-O8: Runs interviewer calibration program ensuring consistent signal quality and reduced evaluation bias
description: Built interviewer calibration program: monthly sessions reviewing anonymized write-ups, scoring alignment exercises, feedback quality rubric. Interviewer inter-rater reliability improved from 0.4 to 0.75. Reduced 'weak hire' reversals in debrief by 60%.

title: Your Team's Tech Stack Becomes Deprecated Company-Wide
description: Platform team announces your primary framework/language is sunset. Migration timeline is 18 months. You have 100K lines of code in the deprecated stack, active feature development in flight, and no one on your team has deep experience with the target stack.

title: Merging Two Teams After Acquisition/Re-org
description: Company acquired a startup. You're responsible for merging their 8-person team with your 12-person team. Different tech stacks (they use Python/Django, you use Java/Spring), different cultures (startup speed vs. enterprise process), different processes (they have no sprint planning, you run 2-week sprints with full ceremonies). Some role overlap exists. Both teams are anxious about who stays, who leads, and what changes.

title: Managing Through a Major Security Incident (Data Breach)
description: Security team discovers unauthorized data access to your team's service. Customer PII (names, emails, hashed passwords) may be compromised. The scope is unclear — could be hundreds or millions of records. Legal, PR, and the exec team are involved. Your team owns the affected service. The incident is already escalated to the CEO. Clock is ticking on regulatory notification requirements (72 hours under GDPR).

title: Your Skip-Level Reports Are Unhappy With Their EM
description: In skip-level 1:1s, multiple engineers (3 out of 7) express frustration with their EM. Recurring themes: lack of career development conversations, micromanagement on technical decisions, poor communication about team priorities, and feeling unheard. The EM has been in role for 18 months and was promoted from within. Their self-assessment is that things are going well.

title: Budget Is Frozen But Commitments Remain
description: Mid-year budget freeze announced. No new hires (you had 4 open reqs), no new vendor contracts, limited travel and conference budget. But your Q3-Q4 commitments haven't been adjusted. Leadership expects delivery on the original roadmap. Your team is already at capacity, and two of the open reqs were for a critical new initiative that starts next quarter.

title: Leading a Cost Optimization Initiative (FinOps)
description: CFO mandates 30% cloud cost reduction across engineering. You're asked to lead the initiative for your org (4 teams, ~40 engineers). Current monthly spend is $2M across AWS services. No one has a clear picture of what's driving costs. Teams have never been held accountable for infrastructure spend. Finance wants a plan in 2 weeks and results within the quarter.

title: Managing Through a Hiring Freeze
description: 6-month hiring freeze announced company-wide. You have 3 open reqs mid-pipeline — one candidate just passed the onsite, another is in final round, and a third is at phone screen stage. Your team of 9 is already stretched across 3 projects. Two senior engineers are showing signs of burnout. One mid-level engineer recently mentioned they've been getting recruiter outreach. Attrition risk is real and you can't backfill.

title: Your Product Is Being Sunset/Deprecated
description: Leadership decides to sunset your team's product — a service with 50K active users. Revenue doesn't justify continued investment. Users need to be migrated to an alternative (internal or third-party). Timeline is 9 months. Your team of 10 engineers built this product over 3 years. They're anxious about their futures — will they be laid off, reassigned, or forgotten?

title: The IC Trap
description: The IC Trap — EM spends their time writing code and reviewing PRs instead of doing the actual management work their team needs

title: Death by Metrics
description: Death by Metrics — EM drowns the team in dashboards, OKR tracking, and velocity reports until measuring the work consumes more energy than doing the work

title: The Consensus Trap
description: The Consensus Trap — EM treats every decision as requiring unanimous agreement, turning consensus into a procrastination mechanism

title: Meeting Debt
description: Meeting Debt — team drowning in ceremonies and syncs until engineers have less than two hours of uninterrupted focus time per day

title: Documentation Hoarding
description: Documentation Hoarding — EM mandates documentation for everything but never ensures it's maintained, discoverable, or useful, creating a graveyard of stale pages

title: The Hero EM
description: The Hero EM — manager who solves every problem personally, takes over every escalation, and works unsustainable hours while the team never develops independence

title: Quarterly Planning When Product and Engineering Disagree on Priorities
description: It's planning season. Product wants to invest heavily in new features for a key customer segment. Engineering wants to p

title: Asked to Build Something That Conflicts with Your OKRs
description: A VP from another org asks your team to take on an urgent project that doesn't align with your quarterly OKRs. Your mana

title: Your Team's Delivery Predictability Has Collapsed
description: Over the past two quarters, your team has missed 70% of committed sprint goals. Stakeholders are losing trust. The team

title: You Inherit a Team with No Operating Cadence
description: You've just taken over a team that has no regular standup, no sprint planning, no retrospectives, and no documented on-c

title: The Infinite Runway
description: The Infinite Runway — EM treats cloud/infra spend as unbounded and never prioritizes cost optimization

title: Security as Afterthought
description: Security as Afterthought — security reviews happen only after incidents, not as part of the development workflow

title: Compliance Cramming
description: Compliance Cramming — EM treats compliance as a periodic audit exercise rather than continuous posture

title: The Ivory Tower Architect
description: The Ivory Tower Architect — EM pushes architectural purity and over-engineering at the expense of pragmatic delivery

title: The Vanity Dashboard
description: The Vanity Dashboard — EM builds impressive-looking dashboards that measure activity instead of outcomes

title: 1.2: Lead Time for Changes
description: Most actionable DORA metric. Measures time from first commit to production deployment. Decomposes into fixable stages: review wait, build/test, deploy queue. Improving Lead Time naturally improves Deploy Frequency as a side effect.

title: 1.4: Change Failure Rate
description: Percentage of deployments causing failures requiring remediation. Essential quality counterweight to velocity. Without CFR, faster shipping might mean faster breaking. Directly tied to user impact and less gameable than bug counts.

title: 3.3: Error Budget Remaining + Burn Rate
description: The single best arbitration tool between velocity and reliability. Budget remaining tells you whether to ship freely or freeze and fix. Burn rate shows how fast reliability is degrading. Turns political arguments into math and forces SLI/SLO discipline as prerequisite.

title: 3.5: SLO Compliance Rate
description: The Director's reliability scorecard. Answers: 'Which services are chronically unreliable?' Drives investment decisions across the org. Policy-based, not political. Replaces vanity uptime numbers with customer-meaningful thresholds.

title: 5.1: Developer Satisfaction Score
description: Only cheap, reliable leading indicator of attrition, velocity decline, and quality erosion. 5 questions, 10 minutes, quarterly. Every other people metric is lagging. Highest ROI people measurement.

title: 7.1: Regrettable Attrition Rate
description: A single regrettable departure costs $200K-$500K+. The rate alone is insufficient; pattern analysis (themes from exits by team/level/tenure) predicts and prevents the next one. Directors have most leverage here; EMs provide context.

title: 8.4: Engineering Investment Mix
description: Answers 'where does our capacity actually go?' (features vs reliability vs debt vs security). Without this, Directors cannot defend budget, justify headcount, or explain why the roadmap takes longer than expected.

title: 8.2: Revenue / Business Impact Attribution
description: How Directors justify their org's existence. Maps specific engineering work to specific business outcomes. Without it, you're at the mercy of whoever frames the narrative.

title: 2.5: Sprint Commitment Accuracy
description: Best proxy for predictability. 85%+ accuracy earns trust, autonomy, fewer 'when?' questions. Not primary because it's a planning metric, not a delivery system metric — it tells you how well you forecast, not how fast you ship.

title: 1.3: Mean Time to Restore
description: Important but reactive. You can't improve it without incidents to practice on. Heavily influenced by cross-team factors (observability, rollback infra). Primary for incident response maturity, secondary as an ongoing health metric.

title: 5.6: On-Call Burden
description: Fastest path to burnout and attrition. Outsized impact on affected engineers. Not primary because not all teams have significant on-call, and it doesn't aggregate well to org level.

title: 3.1: SLI Definition
description: Essential foundation for error budgets and SLO compliance. The work is in getting the SLI right — choosing user-centric indicators that reflect real customer experience. Once defined correctly, SLIs disappear into the SLO.

title: 3.2: SLO Target
description: SLO targets negotiated with product and SRE. The prerequisite for error budgets. Without defined targets, reliability arguments remain political rather than mathematical.

title: 3.6: Incident Rate by Severity
description: Useful trend but poor primary metric: influenced by classification standards, doesn't capture impact (1 SEV1 > 50 SEV3s), doesn't prescribe action. Best used as context alongside SLO compliance.

title: 8.1: OKR Achievement Rate
description: Primary alignment tool, but achievement rate is secondary as a metric because: OKR quality varies wildly, percentage is influenced by target aggressiveness, and the value of OKRs is in the process, not the score.

title: 5.4: Code Review Turnaround Time
description: Hidden tax on velocity — often 40-60% of Lead Time. Secondary because better decomposed from Lead Time than tracked independently; can be gamed with rubber-stamp fast reviews.

title: 2.6: Blocked Work Rate
description: Best diagnostic for cross-team dependency problems. Secondary because requires disciplined tracking, causes often outside EM control, overlaps with Lead Time decomposition. Most valuable for architectural/reorg arguments.

title: 7.8: eNPS / Engagement Score
description: Useful macro trend — if < 0, something is seriously wrong. Secondary because too coarse to act on, moves slowly, influenced by factors outside your control. Actionable detail comes from DX surveys and exit interviews.

title: 10.1: Cloud Cost per Transaction/User
description: Only cost metric that makes sense at scale because it normalizes for growth. Secondary overall because cost optimization that degrades reliability or velocity is a false economy. Fix delivery and reliability first.

title: 3.7: Post-Incident Action Item Completion Rate
description: Process discipline metric. Secondary because completion without quality is hollow, and the effect of good follow-through shows up in declining incident rate and improving SLO compliance.

title: 9.1: Vulnerability Remediation Time
description: Only continuously relevant security metric. Secondary overall because managed through organizational process rather than sprint-level decisions. But Critical SLA (<24hrs) is non-negotiable.

title: 4.3: Rollback Rate
description: Most unambiguous quality signal — either you rolled back or you didn't. Secondary because all quality metrics are lagging, and CFR + error budget are better leading signals.

title: 5.2: Developer Toil Hours
description: Valuable for justifying platform/automation investment. Secondary because relies on self-reporting (inconsistent), impact shows up in DX scores and velocity more reliably, and 'toil' is subjective. Best used for specific business cases.

title: 1.1: Deployment Frequency
description: Most cited DORA metric but least useful as a primary: most gameable (split deploys), lagging indicator of Lead Time (LT improves → DF rises naturally), varies wildly by architecture. DF is a side effect of good Lead Time, not a goal.

title: 2.1: Flow Time
description: Overlaps with DORA Lead Time. Adds value only when you need to distinguish queue time from active work time. Keep in toolkit for deep dives, not on main dashboard.

title: 2.3: Cycle Time
description: Useful for estimation calibration but less powerful than Lead Time because it doesn't capture the deploy pipeline.

title: 2.4: Throughput
description: Capacity planning input, not health metric. Items vary in size, making raw counts misleading. Sprint Commitment Accuracy is a better delivery health measure.

title: 2.2: WIP (Work in Progress)
description: Process hygiene metric, not strategic signal. Consequences of high WIP are better measured through Lead Time and Cycle Time directly. Useful as a coaching tool in retros.

title: 4.4: Escaped Defect Rate
description: Useful for root-cause analysis but requires subjective classification. Business impact of escaped defects better captured through CFR and incident rate.

title: 4.1: Test Coverage (Critical Paths)
description: Most misleading quality metric in software. High coverage ≠ good tests. Use as code review conversation, not a KPI. The signal you want is 'do tests catch bugs?' — better measured through escaped defects and CFR.

title: 4.2: Flaky Test Rate
description: Developer experience problem more than quality problem. Impact shows up in CI cycle time and DX scores. Flaky rate helps diagnose why DX is low, but DX score is the primary signal.

title: 5.3: Build & CI Cycle Time
description: Subset of Lead Time. Typically a platform team problem, not an EM decision. Impact captured through DX survey and Lead Time decomposition.

title: 5.5: Cognitive Load Index
description: DevEx framework identifies cognitive load as a core dimension. AI paradoxically increases cognitive load when engineers must verify, debug, and understand code they didn't write.

title: 5.7: Environment Setup Time
description: Only matters during onboarding. Fix it once, check quarterly.

title: 5.8: IDP Adoption Rate
description: Only relevant if you have a platform team. Adoption is a lagging indicator of platform quality. Impact shows up in CI time, setup time, and DX scores.

title: 7.2: Non-Regrettable Attrition Rate
description: If non-regrettable attrition is 0%, you're not managing performance. Healthy range: 2-5% annually.

title: 7.3: Time to Hire
description: Mostly recruiting operations, not engineering leadership. EM's lever is narrow (be responsive in interviews).

title: 7.4: Offer Acceptance Rate
description: Small sample sizes make it noisy. Root causes usually comp or brand (outside EM control).

title: 7.5: New Hire Ramp Time
description: Impact of slow ramp shows up in delivery metrics. Measured per hire; improves with one-time investments in onboarding.

title: 7.6: Span of Control
description: Changes infrequently (only reorgs/hiring). Effects of bad span show up in DX, attrition, delivery long before you notice the number. Check during reorgs.

title: 7.7: Diversity Metrics
description: Not tertiary because they don't matter — they matter enormously. They operate on a different cadence and accountability structure. Pipeline and retention diversity are strategic, quarterly/annual concerns in hiring reviews and org planning. Parallel track, not lower priority.

title: 8.3: Cost of Delay
description: Powerful but expensive to calculate. Only worth doing for major initiatives (>1 quarter of team effort). Use for specific high-stakes decisions, not ongoing tracking.

title: 8.5: Customer Impact Metrics
description: Essential for product teams but influenced by many non-engineering factors. Engineering-specific impact is better captured through SLO compliance and revenue attribution.

title: 8.6: Tech Debt Ratio
description: Important but imprecise. 'Tech debt' is subjective. Impact shows up in Lead Time, CFR, DX scores. Better to measure 'how much are we investing in reducing it?' (Investment Mix) and 'is velocity improving?' (outcome).

title: 9.2: Dependency Currency
description: Preventive hygiene metric. Consequences show up in vulnerability remediation time. Largely automatable (Dependabot, Renovate). Set up, automate, check monthly.

title: 9.3: Compliance Audit Readiness
description: Situational (regulated industries). Episodic (audit season). Primarily documentation. Invest once in automation, then monitor.

title: 10.2: Infrastructure Utilization Rate
description: FinOps operational metric, not leadership metric. Impact shows up in cost per transaction.

title: 10.3: Cost per Engineer (Fully Loaded)
description: Financial planning input, not engineering metric. Useful for ROI modeling, never on a dashboard.

title: 10.4: Revenue per Engineer
description: Terrible operational metric: penalizes platform teams, varies by business model, influenced by factors outside engineering control, incentivizes headcount reduction over productivity. Annual narrative only.

title: 6.1: PR Throughput (Team)
description: Spot blocked teams, detect sudden disruption. A >50% week-over-week drop warrants immediate investigation. Team-level diagnostic only — never for individual performance.

title: 6.2: PR Size Distribution
description: Large PRs correlate with higher defect rates and slower reviews. If >30% of PRs are XL (>1000 lines), PR hygiene coaching is needed. Never penalize engineers for large PRs without context.

title: 6.3: Review Load Distribution
description: Bus factor risk and reviewer burnout signal. If one person is doing >50% of team reviews, rotation problem needs addressing. Never use review count as performance metric.

title: 6.4: Meeting Load
description: Context switching and focus time erosion. ICs with >12 hrs/week in meetings need a calendar audit. Categorizing meetings as 'valuable' vs 'theater' creates political conflict; effect shows up in DX scores.

title: 6.5: Cross-Team Dependency Count
description: Quantify organizational coupling for reorg/API arguments. >3 active dependencies per sprint warrants an architecture/ownership investigation. Evidence for org redesign, not blame.

title: I1: Lines of Code per Engineer
description: Encourages bloated code; punishes refactoring, deletions, and concise solutions; penalizes debugging and design work. Universally discredited.

title: I2: Commits per Engineer
description: Micro-commits, noisy history, gaming; penalizes pairing, mobbing, and thoughtful architecture work.

title: I3: Tickets Closed per Engineer
description: Ticket slicing; busy work tickets; resistance to complex/ambiguous problems; penalizes systems thinking.

title: I4: Story Points per Engineer
description: Immediate point inflation; distorts estimation; turns planning tool into performance weapon; destroys trust between eng and product.

title: I5: Velocity (Points/Sprint) as KPI
description: Point inflation, scope slicing, conservative estimation; rewards gaming over delivery. Velocity should be stable (for planning), not increasing (proof of productivity).

title: I6: Raw Bug Count
description: Punishes honest reporting; encourages hiding/reclassifying bugs; ignores severity entirely.

title: I7: % Bugs Fixed per Sprint
description: Encourages tiny, low-impact fixes; defers hard systemic issues.

title: I8: Test Coverage % (Headline)
description: Easily gamed (meaningless assertions); high coverage coexists with poor quality; creates false confidence.

title: I9: % Time Spent Coding
description: Ignores necessary non-coding work (design, mentoring, incidents, planning); penalizes seniors and leaders; treats humans as resources to be utilized.

title: I10: Total Attrition Rate (Unclassified)
description: Treats all departures as equivalent; can't distinguish healthy turnover from crisis; hides systemic issues.

title: I11: Uptime % (Without Defined SLI)
description: 'What was up?' matters more than 'were we up?' 99.99% on a metric users don't feel is wasted effort; no defined measurement boundary; no error budget policy.

title: I12: Topline Revenue as Eng Metric
description: Revenue is multi-causal (marketing, sales, pricing, seasonality); attribution to engineering is impossible at this level; creates false credit or false blame.

title: I13: NPS Owned Solely by Engineering
description: NPS influenced by support, pricing, UX, policies, market position; engineering is one of many factors; attribution is nearly impossible.

title: I14: Build Success Rate
description: Near-100% often means tests aren't catching anything; the information value of a failed build is high. Distinguish flaky failures from legitimate failures.

title: I15: Individual PR Count
description: Trivially gamed; penalizes mentoring, design, architecture, code review, incident response; destroys trust instantly when used in perf reviews.

title: Velocity ↔ Quality
description: Speed without a quality check incentivizes shipping broken code fast. Quality without a speed check incentivizes paralysis.

title: Reliability ↔ Velocity
description: Reliability without velocity tracking leads to over-engineering. Velocity without reliability tracking leads to chaos. Error budgets exist specifically to balance these.

title: People ↔ Delivery
description: Happy teams that don’t ship aren’t sustainable. Productive teams that are miserable won’t last. You need both to know if performance is real and sustainable.

title: Investment ↔ Outcome
description: Knowing where capacity goes is useless without knowing what it produced. Knowing what was produced without knowing what was invested is accidental, not strategic.

title: Incidents ↔ Follow-Through
description: Counting incidents without tracking whether you fixed root causes means you’ll count the same incidents again next quarter.

title: Attrition ↔ Classification
description: Raw attrition rate is meaningless. Losing a low performer you were about to PIP is healthy. Losing your Staff engineer to a competitor is a crisis. Without classification, you can’t tell the difference.

title: Lead Time spiking
description: Is this one team’s problem (process) or multiple teams’ problem (platform/architecture)?

title: CFR climbing
description: Is quality declining because of testing gaps (invest in testing) or because people are overloaded (invest in capacity)?

title: Error Budget burning fast
description: Are we having new types of failures (architecture) or repeating old ones (follow-through failure)?

title: SLO Compliance dropping
description: Is this a capacity/architecture problem (invest) or a process/discipline problem (coach)?

title: DX Score dropping
description: Is this a tooling problem (platform investment) or a workload problem (capacity/scope)?

title: Regrettable Attrition rising
description: Is this a specific team/manager problem or an org-wide systemic issue?

title: Sprint Commitment <70%
description: Are we bad at planning (estimation) or bad at protecting capacity (interrupts)?

title: OKR Achievement <50%
description: Are OKRs failing because they’re bad OKRs (alignment) or because we can’t execute (delivery)?

title: Cost per Transaction rising
description: Is this a resource management problem (FinOps) or an architecture problem (engineering investment)?

title: 5.9: AI Tool Adoption & Trust Score
description: Track % of team using AI tools, trust level, and the gap between perceived and measured AI benefit.

title: 7.9: Burnout Risk Index
description: Based on Maslach dimensions: energy exhaustion, cynicism, reduced professional efficacy. Survey 3 items quarterly.

title: 9.4: AI-Generated Code Security Scan Rate
description: % of AI-generated code receiving security-specific review beyond standard CI.

title: AI-1: AI-Assisted PR Ratio
description: % of PRs containing AI-generated code. Establishes baseline for correlating AI adoption with quality.

title: AI-2: AI PR Quality Delta
description: Difference in CFR, rollback rate, and escaped defect rate between AI-assisted and human-authored PRs.

title: AI-3: Verification Overhead Ratio
description: Review time for AI PRs divided by review time for human PRs. Measures the verification bottleneck.

title: AI-4: AI Readiness Score
description: Composite score based on DORA AI Capabilities Model. Predicts whether AI will amplify or destabilize your org.

title: 10.5: AI Tooling ROI
description: AI tool cost per engineer vs measured delivery improvement. Is the AI investment working?

title: I16: AI Perceived Speed Gain
description: 80%+ report gains but RCTs show 19% slowdown. Measure outcomes, not perceptions.

title: AI Throughput ↔ Verification
description: AI accelerates code generation while reviews become rubber stamps. Without verification metrics, bug rates climb silently.

title: AI adoption but no delivery improvement
description: Are we missing AI prerequisites or is AI genuinely not suited to this codebase?

title: Harmonious High-Achievers
description: Virtuous cycle of sustainable excellence. High stability, fast cadence, low friction, exceptional culture.

title: Pragmatic Performers
description: Sustainable balance of speed and stability. Predictable delivery. Mature platform foundation.

title: Stable and Methodical
description: Prioritize quality and reliability above all. Deliberate, high-quality delivery.

title: High-Impact, Low-Cadence
description: Brilliant output but severe delivery bottlenecks. Structural understaffing and dependency stalls.

title: Constrained by Process
description: Bureaucratic treadmill. Momentum destroyed by approvals, CABs, excessive meetings.

title: Legacy Bottleneck
description: Capable engineers trapped in reactive firefighting against unstable, aging architecture.

title: Foundational Challenges
description: Constant high-pressure firefighting. Chronic slow delivery and systemic instability.

title: Chaotic High-Variance
description: Oscillation between great sprints and terrible sprints. Unpredictable delivery with wild metric swings.

title: Specialized Silo
description: Deep expertise in narrow domains with minimal cross-training. High bus factor — metrics look OK but organization is fragile.

title: Stalled Transformation
description: Mid-migration between architectures or platforms. Not broken but not stable. Fragile state.

title: Getting Started with Metrics
description: 30-minute onboarding path: pick your role, identify your team archetype, follow your starter sequence.

title: Metrics by Archetype
description: Recommended metrics, dashboards, and diagnostic chains tailored to each organizational archetype.

title: C12-O6: Maintains cultural continuity through leadership transitions and team growth
description: When onboarding a new tech lead, pairs them with culture carriers and ensures they absorb existing norms before introducing changes. During rapid growth, scales culture through structured mentoring rather than hoping new hires absorb it organically.

title: C12-O7: Creates explicit feedback channels ensuring every voice is heard, not just the loudest
description: Implements anonymous team health surveys, rotating meeting facilitators, and written-first discussion formats that ensure introverts and underrepresented voices have equal opportunity to contribute.

title: C12-O8: Proactively addresses toxic behaviors before they become normalized team patterns
description: When observing dismissive code review comments from a senior engineer, addresses it in 1:1 within 24 hours, resets expectations with the team publicly, and monitors for recurrence rather than waiting for an HR complaint.

title: C10-O6: Presents resource requests as tiered options with quantified trade-offs for each level
description: Instead of requesting 5 headcount, presents three options: (A) 2 heads — deliver core features only, delay platform work 6 months; (B) 4 heads — core + platform, accept tech debt in monitoring; (C) 6 heads — full roadmap with reliability investment. Each option includes timeline, risk, and ROI.

title: C10-O7: Tracks and communicates cost-per-outcome to demonstrate engineering ROI
description: Maintains a running dashboard showing cost-per-feature, cost-per-customer-served, and engineering investment by workstream category (growth, reliability, platform, debt). Uses this to justify investments and identify efficiency opportunities.

title: C10-O8: Proactively reallocates capacity to highest-impact work without waiting for top-down direction
description: When a planned project's expected impact decreases due to market changes, proposes reallocating two engineers to a higher-ROI reliability initiative without waiting for quarterly planning. Communicates the shift with data and gets alignment within a week.

title: C7-O8: Structures difficult conversations with preparation, empathy, and clear follow-through
description: Before delivering a promotion rejection, documents specific gaps with examples, prepares a development plan, schedules a private 1:1 with sufficient time, delivers the message with empathy, and follows up with written summary and action items within 24 hours.

title: C7-O9: Scales communication systems as org grows — replaces hallway decisions with documented processes
description: As team grows from 8 to 25 engineers, replaces informal decision-making with an RFC process, introduces weekly written status updates replacing daily syncs, and creates tiered communication channels (urgent/informational/discussion).

title: C7-O10: Distributes decision authority using clear frameworks — knows which decisions need consensus vs. a driver
description: Maintains a decision authority matrix: team norms require consensus, technical design decisions use DACI with tech lead as Driver, tooling choices are delegated to individual engineers, and architecture bets require EM + TL alignment. Team knows which decisions they can make autonomously.

title: C14-O7: Maintains continuous performance signal through ongoing documentation, not end-of-cycle reconstruction
description: Keeps running performance notes for each report updated weekly. When review cycle arrives, has 6 months of specific examples ready — not scrambling to remember what happened. Shares feedback themes in 1:1s monthly so reviews contain zero surprises.

title: C14-O8: Manages high performers with differentiated development plans and retention-conscious conversations
description: Identifies top performers' growth aspirations proactively, creates stretch assignments aligned to next-level expectations, has quarterly career conversations (not just at review time), and flags retention risks to leadership before they become emergencies.

title: C2-O5: Maintains an explicit 'not doing' list that communicates strategic trade-offs to stakeholders
description: Quarterly planning output includes not just the roadmap but a named list of requests deliberately declined with rationale. Stakeholders understand what was deprioritized and why, reducing re-litigation.

title: C2-O6: Connects engineering investment to business outcomes with measurable success criteria
