description: Every major engineering initiative has defined success metrics tied to business outcomes before work begins. Team can articulate why they're building what they're building in business terms, not just technical terms.

title: C8-O7: Builds system resilience through proactive chaos engineering and game days
description: Schedules quarterly game days that simulate production failures with heroes explicitly excluded. Tests runbook accuracy, on-call readiness, and failover procedures before real incidents occur.

title: C8-O8: Manages error budgets to balance reliability investment against feature velocity
description: Defines SLOs with product team and maintains error budgets. When budget is consumed, automatically shifts team focus to reliability work. When budget is healthy, uses it to justify faster feature shipping with acceptable risk.

title: AP-40: The Missing Stair — EM tolerates a known toxic or underperforming person because the team has learned to 'work around' them
description: New hires warned informally about 'how to handle' a specific person; team has workarounds for someone's behavior; complaints in skip-levels about someone EM hasn't addressed; code review avoidance patterns around one person; 1:1s with other reports frequently mention the same person

title: AP-41: Culture Tourism — EM treats culture building as periodic events (off-sites, pizza, team lunches) rather than daily structural practices
description: Team building = quarterly off-sites; culture initiative = Slack emoji reactions; no written team norms; culture conversations only happen when engagement scores drop; fun activities substituted for addressing real team dysfunction; 'we have great culture' but people are leaving

title: AP-42: Peanut Butter Spreading — EM distributes resources evenly across all projects instead of concentrating on highest-impact bets
description: Every project gets exactly 1-2 engineers; no project has enough resources to succeed; everything moves slowly; nothing gets killed; team feels spread thin; 'we're working on everything' but shipping nothing meaningful

title: AP-43: The Telephone Game — information degrades as it passes through management layers because there's no source-of-truth documentation
description: Team's understanding of strategy differs from leadership's intent; 'I heard from my manager who heard from their manager' is common; written strategy docs don't exist or are stale; different teams interpret the same directive differently; confusion after all-hands about what was actually decided

title: AP-44: The Recency Trap — EM's performance assessment dominated by last 6 weeks instead of full review period, rewarding or punishing based on timing rather than sustained performance
description: Review feedback mostly references recent projects; engineers who had strong H1 but quiet H2 get middling reviews; someone's one mistake in November overshadows 10 months of excellence; EM can't cite specific examples from early in the review period; performance rating correlates with what happened last month, not the full cycle

title: P-C12-3: Your Team Culture Is Deteriorating After Rapid Growth
description: Your team doubled from 6 to 12 in 3 months. Skip-level feedback reveals new hires feel excluded, original team members feel their culture is gone, and collaboration norms are breaking down.

title: P-C12-4: Addressing a Toxic Senior Engineer the Team Works Around
description: Your most technically skilled senior engineer is dismissive in code reviews, dominates discussions, and makes junior engineers afraid to speak up. The team has learned to 'work around' this person, but you're losing good people.

title: P-C10-4: Asked to Do More With Fewer People After Layoffs
description: After a round of layoffs, your team lost 3 of 10 engineers. Leadership still expects the same deliverables. Team morale is low, survivors are anxious, and you need to figure out what's actually possible.

title: P-C7-2: Communicating a Major Technical Decision Not Everyone Agrees With
description: After an RFC process, you've decided to migrate from microservices back to a modular monolith. Senior engineers are split — some are excited, others feel their microservices expertise is being devalued. You need to communicate the decision without creating factions.

title: P-C7-3: Your Team Has Communication Debt — Decisions Aren't Documented
description: Your team has grown from 5 to 15 people. Key technical decisions live in Slack threads, hallway conversations, and individual memories. New hires can't find context. The same decisions are relitigated monthly. You're drowning in 'quick syncs'.

title: P-C14-3: High Performer Wants Promotion But Isn't Ready
description: Your best engineer is pushing hard for promotion to Senior. They're technically excellent and deliver consistently, but they lack the influence, mentoring, and scope leadership expected at the next level. They're getting impatient and you're worried about retention.
